0.text: Sadness is a natural emotion that everyone experiences from time to time. It can be a reaction to specific events or situations. However, when sadness becomes constant and starts to affect daily life, it may be a sign of depression.
0.fact: According to the World Health Organization, about 5% of adults worldwide live with depression. Early detection and seeking help can significantly improve quality of life and support a faster recovery.

1.text: Fear is a natural response to threat. It helps us avoid danger and protect ourselves. However, when fear becomes constant and no longer matches real threats, it may be a sign of depression.
1.fact: Studies show that about 20% of people experience fear and anxiety related to the future, especially in times of uncertainty and instability. Understanding and managing these feelings can help improve mental health and quality of life.

2.text: Feeling like a failure and having a negative self-image are common companions of depression. People tend to see their successes as less important and their failures as more significant than they really are.
2.fact: It is important to remember that, in most cases, people tend to exaggerate their failures. According to the American Psychological Association, only about 25% of people who see themselves as failures actually have objective reasons to think so.

3.text: Not being able to enjoy everyday things such as hobbies, food or time with loved ones is called anhedonia. It is one of the core symptoms of depression.
3.fact: Anhedonia can be caused by a variety of factors, including biological ones (for example, changes in neurotransmitter levels) and psychological ones (such as chronic stress or trauma).

4.text: Guilt is a natural emotion that helps us regulate our behavior and maintain social ties. However, constant or excessive guilt can be a symptom of depression.
4.fact: Chronic guilt can contribute to the development of other mental health conditions, such as anxiety disorders and obsessive–compulsive disorder (OCD).

5.text: Therapies such as cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) have proven effective in reducing fear of being judged. These approaches help change negative thinking patterns and improve self-acceptance.
5.fact: According to the U.S. National Institute of Mental Health, about 12% of people experience social anxiety at some point in their lives.

6.text: Self-compassion practices and accepting your own imperfections have been shown to be effective in reducing self-hatred. Research shows that people who engage in mindfulness and compassion-based practices are less likely to experience intense self-criticism.
6.fact: Self-hatred is a common symptom of depression and anxiety disorders. It can contribute to the development of other mental health conditions, such as personality disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

7.text: Self-criticism is an inner dialogue in which we judge and condemn ourselves for mistakes and failures. This thinking pattern often accompanies depression and anxiety disorders.
7.fact: Oprah Winfrey, a well-known TV host and entrepreneur, has repeatedly shared her struggles with self-criticism. In interviews and books she has described how difficult it was to accept her mistakes on the way to success. Oprah actively promotes self-compassion and self-acceptance practices, which helped her overcome negative feelings and find inner peace.

8.text: Suicidal thoughts are a serious symptom of depression and other mental health conditions. It is important to understand that having such thoughts requires immediate attention and support from professionals.
8.fact: According to the World Health Organization, around 800,000 people die by suicide every year. It is one of the leading causes of death among young people aged 15 to 29.

9.text: Chronic worry can affect physical health, causing symptoms such as headaches, muscle tension and digestive problems. Research shows that anxiety disorders are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease.
9.fact: Adele, the famous British singer, has spoken openly about her problems with anxiety and panic attacks. Despite her huge success, she often experienced intense worry before performances and in everyday life. Adele has used various methods, including therapy and meditation, to cope with her anxiety.

10.text: Lack of sleep and overwork can significantly increase irritability. Studies show that chronic sleep deprivation raises levels of stress hormones such as cortisol, which in turn increases irritability.
10.fact: According to the American Psychological Association, about 50% of people with depression report persistent irritability as a major symptom.

11.text: Taking part in support groups or therapy groups can help restore interest in social contact. Such groups provide a safe space to share feelings and receive support from others who face similar difficulties.
11.fact: J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series, has spoken in interviews about her struggle with depression, when she felt a loss of interest in people and communication. She emphasized the importance of social support and professional help in overcoming this state.

12.text: Neuropsychological research shows that depression can alter activity in the prefrontal cortex, the brain area responsible for decision-making and planning.
12.fact: Psychotherapy, especially cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), can help improve decision-making skills. CBT helps people develop more adaptive thinking strategies and reduce the influence of negative emotions on cognitive processes.

13.text: Changes in how a person sees their own appearance are often linked to psychological conditions such as depression and anxiety disorders. People with depression often have a negative view of themselves and their looks, even if there have been no objective changes.
13.fact: Lady Gaga, the famous singer and actress, has spoken openly about her struggles with body image and depression. She has shared that she often felt unattractive and worried about her appearance, despite recognition and success.

14.text: According to the World Health Organization, depression is a leading cause of disability worldwide. It affects more than 264 million people and leads to significant economic losses due to reduced productivity.
14.fact: Psychotherapy, especially cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and medication can help restore motivation and improve the ability to work. CBT helps people develop more adaptive thinking strategies and cope with negative emotions.

15.text: Sleep quality is directly linked to mental health. Lack of sleep can worsen mood, cognitive functions and overall well-being, creating a vicious cycle where poor sleep worsens mental health and poor mental health worsens sleep.
15.fact: Insomnia increases the risk of developing depression and anxiety disorders by 20–40%.

16.text: Persistent fatigue is one of the most common symptoms of depression and chronic stress. Fatigue can be both physical and mental, reducing the ability to handle daily tasks and take part in social activities.
16.fact: Winston Churchill, former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, suffered from depression, which he called his ‘black dog’. He often mentioned feeling constantly tired and lacking energy, despite his active and productive life.

17.text: According to the World Health Organization, depression is a leading cause of changes in eating habits and disordered eating in adults.
17.fact: Healthy eating and regular meals can help stabilize appetite and improve overall mental state. Research shows that diets rich in omega-3 fatty acids, vitamins and minerals can help reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety.

18.text: Changes in weight can result from shifts in appetite and eating patterns related to depression and anxiety disorders. Unintentional, significant weight change often indicates serious emotional difficulties.
18.fact: Carrie Fisher, the famous actress known for her role in Star Wars, spoke openly about her struggle with depression and bipolar disorder. She described how these conditions affected her weight and appetite. Carrie actively worked to raise awareness about mental illness and the importance of seeking help.

19.text: Somatization is a process in which psychological stress manifests as physical symptoms, such as pain, digestive issues or dental problems. This is often seen in people with depression and anxiety disorders.
19.fact: Mental state can significantly influence the perception of pain. Studies show that depression and anxiety can lower the pain threshold and increase sensitivity to physical discomfort.

20.text: Changes in levels of hormones such as serotonin and dopamine play a key role in regulating mood and sexual interest. Depression and anxiety disorders can disrupt this balance, leading to a decrease in libido.
20.fact: Research shows that about 70% of people with depression experience reduced libido and sexual interest.

normal.text: Your result falls within the normal range. People with this level usually feel more stable and calm, and more often experience satisfaction with life. Keep supporting your emotional well-being and taking care of yourself.
normal.title: Normal state

mild.text: Your state is still within the bounds of normal, but you may notice some emotional instability or low mood. A light ‘psychological tune-up’ can help: mindfulness practices, CBT-based exercises and support from loved ones. Small changes in how you approach everyday life often bring noticeable relief.
mild.title: Mild depression

moderate.text: Your result may indicate depression of moderate severity. You may be facing significant emotional discomfort and difficulties in daily life. If this state has lasted for more than two weeks, it would be helpful to seek professional support. You do not have to cope with this on your own.
moderate.title: Moderate depression

exacerbated.text: Your result may point to pronounced depressive symptoms. You may experience strong emotional strain and a marked decrease in vitality. At this stage professional help is especially important. Please reach out to a specialist — this is a step toward improvement, and real help is available.
exacerbated.title: Severe depressive state

text: The BDI (Beck Depression Inventory) is a valid tool for assessing depressive states and is widely used by professionals. It helps determine the level of emotional distress and track changes over time.

We recommend taking the test periodically to observe your dynamics and notice shifts early. Remember that the test results are only a guide, not a final diagnosis. If you feel that life is hard right now, reaching out for support is a brave and important step.
